really.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: It was really cold last night.
really.translation[0].definitions[0].not: Really is especially frequent in spoken English. In writing, people usually prefer to use very or extremely to emphasize an adjective, or very much to emphasize a verb:
really.translation[0].definitions[1].def: used when you are talking about what actually happened or is true, rather than what people might wrongly think
really.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Why don’t you tell us what really happened?
I never know what he’s really thinking.
She seems unfriendly at first, but she’s really very nice.
really.translation[0].definitions[2].def: used to emphasize something you are saying
really.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: We really need that extra money.
really.translation[0].definitions[3].def: used in questions when you are asking someone if something is true and suggesting that you think it is not true
really.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Do you really think she’s doing this for your benefit?
Do you really expect me to believe that?
really.translation[0].definitions[4].def: used to show that you are surprised by what someone has said
really.translation[0].definitions[5].def: used in conversation to show that you are listening to or interested in what the other person is saying
really.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: ‘We had a great time in Florida.’ ‘Really? How lovely.’
really.translation[0].definitions[6].def: used to show that you agree with someone
really.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: ‘Glen can be such a jerk.’ ‘Yeah, really!’
really.translation[0].definitions[7].def: used to show that you are angry or disapprove of something
really.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: Really, Larry, you might have told me!
